Ajahn Chah was Ajahn Brahm’s teacher.
Jhana Grove is the name of the BSWA Meditation Centre near Perth.
Samādhi is the stillness of mind in deep meditation.
In this context, nimitta means the perception of bright light that normally appears before jhāna.
Brahmavaṁso is Ajahn Brahm’s full monastic name.
Ajahn Mun was a famous Thai Buddhist meditation monk.
Enlightenment means freedom from suffering. Nibbāna in Pāli.
The teaching of the Buddha is known as Dharma, which is spelt Dhamma in Pāli.
The Suttas are the Buddha’s discourses.
Māra is the Evil One or the Tempter.
Kamma or karma means deed. ‘Unfortunate kamma’ here was used to mean ‘bad luck’.
Mettā is loving-kindness or friendliness.
Bodhinyana Monastery is a Buddhist forest monastery in Western Australia and the home Ajahn Brahm.
The Paṭisambhidāmagga, known in English as the Path of Analytical Discernment, is part of the Khuddaka Nikāya, the fifth and last collection of discourses in the Theravada Canon.
For instance, in the Dhammacakkappavattanasutta at SN 56.11.
Ekag­gatā means unification or oneness of mind.
The Vinaya is the monastic law for fully ordained Buddhist monks and nuns
Devadatta was a monk who split the Saṅgha and attempted to kill the Buddha.
The term “Saṅgha” refers to the Buddhist monastic community of monks and nuns.
See the Notes section at the back of this book for the full text.
Ānanda was the Buddha's cousin and attendant
An arahant is a fully enlightened or awakened being
‘Rotten fish curry’ is what Ajahn Brahm called a north-east curry made with fermented freshwater fish.
Buddha Kassapa was one of the previous Buddhas mentioned in the Pali Canon.
Sāriputta was one of the Buddha’s chief disciples and foremost in wisdom.
Stream-winner is the first stage of enlightenment.
Vedanā means feeling, sensation, saññā means perception, saṅ­khā­ra means willed activities.
The story of the first communal recitation, or Council, is given in the Chapter on the Group of Five Hundred, Pañcasatikakkhandhaka of the Vinaya Piṭaka, at Kd 21
A bhik­khu­nī is a fully ordained Buddhist nun
For more on Dependent Cessation see the booklet Dependent Liberation by Ajahn Brahmali on theMettāShelf
